channel.title: Waffle on Vacuum weblog from Edward Vielmetti
channel.description: Recent content in Waffle on Vacuum weblog from Edward Vielmetti

item.title: Using Github Issues and Waffle.io as a personal kanban board
item.description: I’ve been using Github issues to track my personal todo list for quite some time now, and since November I’ve been using Waffle.io to help that process. Waffle in this use is a view of a series of queues in my todo list. Most everything that I’m not doing now lives in the “backlog” queue, which I try to keep to less than 100 just to keep myself sane. (At more than 100 there’s usually a lot of duplicates; at less than 100 I’m probably not acknowledging that there’s something to be done).

item.title: Github-based kanban boards: Zenhub, Waffle, Huboard, Blossom et al
item.description: A kanban board is simply a two-dimensional view of a series of work queues. By moving a piece of work from one column to another, you update its status. This gives you a quick way to visualize your current priorities, as well as making it very clear when one or more of your queues are too full. I've been using Github issues as a personal issue tracker for a while, using its milestones feature to track categories.
